Base Smart Card Cryptographic Service Provider

descripGrp.descrip: The basic software module for by smart cards that performs cryptography and includes algorithms for authentication, encoding, and encryption.
The API that supports PKI and X.509 certificates, such as certificate chain validation, certificate stores, and signature verification.
The API that supports PKI and X.509 certificates, such as certificate chain validation, certificate stores, and signature verification.
A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.
A configuration mode for the Certificate Enrollment Web Service in which it will only process renewal requests.
A hexadecimal string that contains the SHA-1 hash of the certificate.

In Server Manager and Event Viewer, the urgency of an event or error condition, system fault, failure, or action by either the system or the user. Severity can be any of four industry-standard values: Information, Warning, Error, or Critical. These values are defined in the Event Viewer Help.

In Windows PowerShell, a script that runs when Windows PowerShell or Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) starts. The profile script sets up and customizes the Windows PowerShell environment and can contain cmdlets, scripts, functions, or any valid Windows PowerShell command.
A process that builds one or more certificate paths. The certificate paths may or may not trace up to a self-signed or root certificate.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificate’s AKI extension to a CA certificate’s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificate’s AKI extension to a CA certificate’s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.
An order process where an item is assembled to satisfy a sales order just before the order is shipped to the customer.
An order process where an item is assembled and then put away in the warehouse as a sellable item.
A content of a kit item that may consist of one or more components (that are raw materials, regular sellable items, or kit items), resources, and text comments.
To commit to a particular payment amount, causing those funds to eventually be transferred from the issuing bank to the merchant's account in the acquiring bank.
A pick where the quantity handled is higher than the required quantity of the source document.

An entity that is responsible for deducting the money from the customer credit card account and moving the money to or from the merchant's account. The user of the payment service will have to sign up with one or more payment providers.
A timeframe that is used to avoid minor rescheduling of existing supply out in time. Changes from the supply date until one dampener period from the supply date will not generate any action messages.
A type of account in the general ledger for inventory transactions that await further processing, but whose interim value must be visible in the general ledger.
A timeframe that defines the recurring planning horizon of the item and defines the frequency for checking if projected inventory reaches or goes below the reorder point.

A period of time that is used to accumulate multiple supply needs into one supply order. From the first planned supply, the system accumulates all supply needs in the following lot accumulation period into one supply, which is placed on the date of the first supply.
Holds bin content that can only be picked for the dedicated resource, such as a machine center, that uses the bin in question
An expense that is not registered or included in source types. You must create it manually. Manual expenses can include expenses such as salaries, interest on credit, or planned investments.

Revenue that is not registered or not included in source types. You must create it manually. Manual revenues can include revenue such as rental income, interest from financial assets, or new private capital.
The physical operation that places the item in a stage bin.

The bin at a dedicated area that contains items or components that are replenished manually. The items are included on component lists like a production BOM for obtaining an exact registration for cost and invoicing purposes, but they are not important or common enough to include on pick lines.
A color between red and blue, identified by the hex number #800080 in the HTML 4 specification.
A deep blue-green color, identified by the hex number #008080 in the HTML 4 specification. An Outlook calendar color palette color.
A feature to manage the creation of sellable items from other sellable items using nonproduction resources.
A supply order that represents a request to fulfill demand for an assembly item by picking items on the assembly BOM or modified on the order and assembling them.
The content of an assembly item that can consist of components, such as raw materials, regular items, or other assembly BOMs, resources, and text lines.
A replenishment policy that is specified on the item card for replenishment by assembly. The two assembly policy options are Assemble-to-Order and Assemble-to-Stock.

An offset value that changes the due date of any assembly order component that belongs to the assembly BOM during replenishment planning. The assembly line due date is then calculated as Due Date = Starting Date - Lead-Time Offset.
The act of taking apart components, resources, or items.

The timeframe during which a suggested new supply date falls to trigger a suggestion to reschedule the supply order. If a suggested new supply date is not within this timeframe, then the suggestion may be to cancel and create a new supply order.
A quantity by which you allow projected inventory to exceed the reorder point before the planning system should suggest decreasing supply orders.
To place a picked item in a bin for internal operations, such as manufacturing.
The location where items are placed for internal operations.
The stage bin where picked components are placed before consumption.

The process that warehouse employees follow to move items from one bin to another bin as requested by internal source documents or because of a previous manual movement. Each inventory movement involves a take and a place action.
The process that warehouse employees follow to move items from one bin to another bin without using a source document.
Transfer an amount from the merchant's account back to the customer's account. The amount can be full or partial.
To cancel a previous authorization and release any hold on funds.
An optional label for allocations that can be used to filter groups of allocations.
A product, product group or service of a company, and a finished good of the company that carry the costs.
The process of allocating costs to particular cost centers or cost objects.
The recurring expenses that are related to the operation of a business or to the operation of a device, component, piece of equipment, or facility.
The ongoing expense of operating a business. Overhead costs can include accounting fees, advertising, depreciation, insurance, interest, legal fees, rent, repairs, supplies, taxes, and so on.
A cost that can be directly allocated to a cost object, such as a material purchase for a specific product.
A variable cost that can change dramatically because it involves large purchases or expenditures that cannot be spread out over time.
The modification of allocation keys by using a multiplier to ensure that allocation is calculated correctly.
Software that enables management of Hotmail email, calendar, and contacts from within Outlook.
Someone with whom a user has established a mutual social relationship.
Pertaining to a user presence state of being unavailable.
Pertaining to a user presence state of being unavailable.
A list of apps and websites of any type that a parent chooses which a child can use at any time and for as long as necessary outside of curfew hours.
An app chosen by a parent that a child can use at any time and for as long as necessary outside of curfew hours.
A website that a child has permission to use anytime outside of curfew hours.
A group of messages that form a conversation between two or more people.
A statement that a device makes to indicate that it can be trusted to access secure resources, such a folder on a file share.

The program that enables developers to connect to Live and easily use Microsoft account, OneDrive, Hotmail, and Messenger within their apps, websites, and devices. Live Connect provides a set of standards-based APIs and the downloadable Live SDK.
A nonfinal release of Windows that's made available to developers.

A statement indicating that the copyright holder reserves, or holds for their own use, all the rights provided by copyright law, such as distribution, performance, and creation of derivative works; that is, they have not waived any such right.
A brief musical composition.
A plan that bills according to data use, such as megabytes downloaded, messages sent, or webpages viewed.
A person or business that makes data or applications available to customers through an online market.
A networking feature that lets one computer directly place information into the memory of another computer.
A networking feature that lets one computer directly place information into the memory of another computer.
A storage pool that exposes physical disks that are currently available for inclusion in a storage pool on a particular storage subsystem.
The layout and general resiliency of data across multiple disks in a virtual disk or storage space.
The layout and general resiliency of data across multiple disks in a virtual disk or storage space.
Pertaining to the resiliency type for a volume that stripes data across physical disks with no resiliency in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
A volume that duplicates data across two or three physical disks in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
Pertaining to the resiliency type for a volume that stripes data and parity information across physical disks in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
A collection of one or more physical disks from a previously created storage pool.
A method of starting the computer that speeds boot time by ending the user session and hibernating the computer, rather than shutting down all running services.

A small amount of executable code contained in the master boot record that scans the partition table for the active partition, finds the starting sector of the active partition, loads a copy of the boot sector from the active partition into memory, and transfers control to the executable code in the boot sector.
A runtime environment for Windows Store apps that's designed to minimize app impact on the computer by placing runtime restrictions on what apps can do.
A filtering feature that monitors downloaded apps for malware or unknown reputation.
A feature of Windows that includes a set of maintenance tasks that run automatically when the user's PC is idle.
A feature of BitLocker that enables IT pros to encrypt a disk before a user begins to use it.
A BitLocker extension that adds management capabilities to BitLocker.
A feature of BitLocker that allows unlocking of an OS volume using a key received over the network.
The Hyper-V technology that runs on the Windows Client operating system, rather than Windows Server.
The ability for IT pros to define how users access a system based on dynamic qualities, such as a user's location or role.
A Windows feature designed to help users avoid data loss by automatically saving versions of files and copies of deleted files so that users can recover them.
The single set of sign-in credentials (email address and password) that provides user access to Microsoft products and services.
A technology that allows for the installation and use of multiple user-interface languages.
A UI element that enables users to locate and select files.
The activation of systems in an enterprise environment by using an established Active Directory implementation and the same key types.
An indicator, such as a message, that informs users of events that are unrelated to their current activity, such as the number of new messages received while their computer is locked.
A transient message that contains relevant, time-sensitive information and that provides quick access to the subject of that content in an app.
A certification program to ensure that devices, systems, and apps are compatible, reliable, and can perform to meet Windows standards.
Tools and documentation to certify apps for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The ability to easily return a PC to a prior state, either by reinstalling Windows and keeping their files or by resetting the PC to the original factory state.
A customized process that identifies and fixes potential problems during PC startup.
The ability for some devices to act like physical smart cards even if they aren't.
The process of activating Windows.
To place at least two fingers on an object and rotate your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A gesture represented by placing at least two fingers on an object and rotating your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A gesture represented by placing at least two fingers on an object and rotating your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
The ActiveX control that facilitates video calling in Hotmail.
A relational data store that's included in Windows and is used by several Windows Services.
A relational data store that's included in Windows and is used by several Windows Services.
A feature that assembles a composite photo collage from multiple source photos.
A process that verifies and eliminates lengthy chkdsk due to any transient errors that NTFS detects.
The process of reducing the number of slabs allocated in thinly provisioned arrays and thinly provisioned virtual disks by rearranging data from sparsely populated slabs to densely populated slabs.
A feature in Windows that communicates with a Microsoft online service to determine a PC's approximate location based on wireless network or IP address info.
An Internet connection created using a metered data plan.
A library of functions and operators that can be combined to build formulas and expressions in Microsoft SQL Server Analysis Services, Power Pivot in Excel, and Power BI Desktop.

A tool in the Windows ADK that uses assessments to create jobs that evaluate quality and view the results after a job runs. The Windows AC can also package a job and other necessary files, save the files in a folder that contains an executable file, move the job to another computer, and then run the job on the new computer.

A tool in the Windows ADK that uses assessments to create jobs that evaluate quality and view the results after a job runs. The Windows AC can also package a job and other necessary files, save the files in a folder that contains an executable file, move the job to another computer, and then run the job on the new computer.
A feature that provides time events that can be used to initiate background work in suspended apps.
A feature that provides time events that can be used to initiate background work in suspended apps.
A contiguous piece of memory.
A color that affects the background and system controls throughout the new Windows user interface.
A graphical representation that is associated with a user local account for Windows or a Microsoft account.
A graphical representation that is associated with a user local account for Windows or a Microsoft account.
A UI element that appears along the top or bottom edge of the screen and may include app commands or navigation.
The area that appears behind the tiles on the Start screen.
The Microsoft app to facilitate the management of events.
The Microsoft app to facilitate the management of events.
An app for making video calls.
An app for making video calls.

A user interface element similar to a button that provides access to key Windows features, such as Start, search, sharing, devices, and settings. Charms differ from buttons in that they have extended functionality, such as flyout menus that provide access to individual or grouped commands.
An application that is built using the traditional Win32 app model, typically makes use of the COM or .NET runtime, and runs only on the desktop of Windows.
The input panel where users can input text through handwriting. The system converts the handwriting to text that users can insert into the active text area.
The Microsoft app for sending and receiving email.
The Microsoft app for sending and receiving email.
The wider of the two apps that can appear on the screen simultaneously after a second app is snapped to the screen.
The app that facilitates SMS and instant messaging.
The app that facilitates SMS and instant messaging.
The app that facilitates SMS and instant messaging.
The app that facilitates the reading of PDF and XPS files.
The app that facilitates the reading of PDF and XPS files.
The app that facilitates contact list and social update management.
The app that facilitates contact list and social update management.
The app that facilitates contact list and social update management.
The app that enables the users to view, organize, edit and share all of their photos from multiple sources.
The app that enables the users to view, organize, edit and share all of their photos from multiple sources.
The app that enables the users to view, organize, edit and share all of their photos from multiple sources.
The app that enables the users to view, organize, edit and share all of their photos from multiple sources.
To move two (or more) fingers toward each other.
To place a finger on the screen and hold it there for a part of a second or more.
A gesture represented by placing a finger on the screen and holding it there for a part of a second or more
To reset the Windows operating system using a method that restores PC settings to defaults but retains a user's files and personalization touches.
To reset the Windows operating system so that all user customizations are removed.
An app that facilitates online file storage.
An app that facilitates online file storage.
To place a finger on the screen, move the finger in one or more directions, and then take the finger off of the screen.
A gesture represented by placing a finger on the screen, moving the finger in one or more directions, and then taking the finger off the screen.
A gesture represented by placing a finger on the screen, moving the finger in one or more directions, and then taking the finger off the screen.
The narrower of the two apps that can appear on the screen simultaneously after a second app is snapped to the screen.
To quickly slide a finger for a short distance.
A gesture represented by a quick slide of a finger over a short distance.
A gesture represented by a quick slide of a finger over a short distance.
A gesture represented by placing a finger or stylus on the screen and then lifting it up, normally within about 0.1 second.
A gesture represented by placing a finger or stylus on the screen and then lifting it up, normally within about 0.1 second.
A word that's suggested as users type, which they can select to quickly insert.
A split on-screen keyboard that is optimized for thumb typing.
A split on-screen keyboard that is optimized for thumb typing.
A moveable object on the Start screen that opens apps or other customized content, like pinned websites.
A contiguous on-screen keyboard.
A contiguous on-screen keyboard.
The brand name of the video offering from Xbox Live.
The brand name of the video offering from Xbox Live.
A feature of Windows that provides a predefined image of a PC from a USB flash drive instead of installing the image on the PC.
An app that facilitates the playing of music.
The app that facilitates the capture of photos and videos by using the PC.
The app that facilitates the capture of photos and videos by using the PC.
To touch an item with two or more fingers and then spread the fingers apart.

An indication that appears on the lock screen or a tile to inform the user of recent activity or updates, such as number of email messages received, since the PC was locked or the app was last viewed.
The feature that audibly reads the text on the screen aloud and describes some events to users.
The feature of Windows for sending tile updates and notifications to users.
The feature of Windows for sending tile updates and notifications to users.
The name of a product in the store that appears to customers. To the end user, this is the name of the product.

Collected data about an app, such as analytics of download, usage, in-application transaction, customer ratings provided by the Windows Store developer portal. This type of information helps developers clearly understand how their applications are doing in the Windows market.
A Windows Store service that enables end users to update apps one at a time or all at the same time for all apps purchased through the Windows Store.
The stage of an app in the certification process.
A link that takes you to a precise location, such as a slide within a presentation, a section of a document, or a specific page within a site, instead of to the main page of the web site.

The SDK for developing on Windows. Developers can confidently select and install this SDK for all Windows apps (both Window Store apps and desktop apps). The SDK is integrated with Visual Studio and also available as a separate download.
An API for AtomPub and syndication.
A feature that a developer provides in an app for consumers to buy from within the app through an in-app purchase transaction.
A transaction performed by a consumer from within the context of an app to buy additional features for that app.

Applications in Windows Store are distributed with user-based licensing model. Windows runtime and application model will only allow applications that are for user-based license as well as signed by Windows Store to be installed/run on Windows 8.
In Windows 8 all windows portal experiences support and persist Live ID logins streamlining the partner experience when working with multiple services and sites.
A type of notification sent via the Microsoft Push Notification Service to an app running on Windows Phone. The format and meaning of the data is determined by the app.
To purchase an app just before downloading and installing it.
To purchase an app after downloading, installing and trying it out.
An image uploaded by the developer that Microsoft can use as a part of promotion via Featured lists and/or marketing campaigns.
The money a developer receives from app and add-on sales in the Windows Store, including advertising revenue.
To move an application into the store. Involves the uploading and certification of an app's packages and listing data.
The beta release of the Windows 8 operating system.
A picture-based sign-in method that authenticates a user by checking gestures made on a picture of the user's own choosing.
To move an object, such as a window or an app, into a locked position on the screen.
An API that contains controls and features that facilitate accessibility.
An API for asset protection, usage control, privacy, and policy application.
An API for accessing and managing system resources.
The title of a screen displaying the list of accent colors.
The service on the phone where you can purchase and download apps.
A feature that automatically corrects errors and makes other substitutions as soon as a user types text.
The picture that appears in the Photos Hub.
The feature to help monitor and save on battery usage.
The feature to help monitor and save on battery usage.
A biography of an artist whose music is in Groove.
An album that contains a continuous roll of live viewfinder and captured photos and videos that have not been archived or moved to other folders.
A Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) network, used by phones that do not have SIM cards.
Non-voice data that a phone exchanges over the air, using the mobile operator's cellular network.
To indicate that a user is in a certain place or location. Users "check in" to a physical place to share their location with their friends.
A card that meets the requirements for use in a Windows Phone.
A digital map indicating the area in which one can expect good cell-phone reception from a specific mobile operator.
A business department that deals with routine inquiries and complaints from customers.
A business department that deals with routine inquiries and complaints from customers.
A theme setting that consists of a black background.
A theme that consists of a light background.

A downloadable app that helps users choose which edition of Windows 8 is right for them, determine if their hardware can support it, determine the compatibility of apps and devices and assist with any changes that are needed, and then purchase and install it from within the app.
An online community that helps you choose how to respond to potential malware threats, and that helps to stop the spread of new malware infections.
An error-handling function of NTFS that is targeted only to corrupted areas to avoid lengthy checkdisk operations.
A process that repairs any errors that the online scan detects.
The feature that allows users to arrange all of their open windows on their screen using the mouse, keyboard, or the Snap Assist feature.
The instructions for how to get from one location to another, either driving or walking.
A mobile broadband or other network for which the provider bills according to data used, such as megabytes downloaded, messages sent, or webpages viewed.
A root certification authority that appears in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities console of the Windows operating systems and is trusted by the operating system.
A root certification authority that appears in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities console of the Windows operating systems and is trusted by the operating system.

An antimalware driver that loads early in the boot process, to evaluate the safety of the other drivers being loaded. Based on a comparison against historical data for those drivers, the antimalware driver returns information to the kernel, which makes initialization decisions for each driver.

An antimalware driver that loads early in the boot process, to evaluate the safety of the other drivers being loaded. Based on a comparison against historical data for those drivers, the antimalware driver returns information to the kernel, which makes initialization decisions for each driver.
The list of different types of application contents, such as games, music and video, lifestyle.
The default language of hubs, tiles, settings, dates, and other headings on the phone.
The category that lists restaurants and bars in a specific neighborhood.
The category that lists restaurants and bars in a specific neighborhood.

The mode the phone goes into after a user calls an emergency number (ex: 911) and the call ends. When the phone is in this mode, only the emergency operator can call the person on their phone, so that the emergency operator can call back or determine where the user is at.
The sub-heading in Local Scout that lists the activities in the area that are taking place over the next few days, and the places or ongoing activities taking place in that area.
The pictures that you can select to appear in the animated Pictures tile on Start, and in the Photos hub.
The collection title for items emphasized by the Store through placement on the site.
The mode that restricts outgoing calls to a fixed set of numbers.
The mode that restricts outgoing calls to a fixed set of numbers.
To alternate between calls when there is an active call and a call on hold.
The network selection mode that enables the phone to bounce between CDMA and GSM network types.
A network used by phones that have SIM cards.
The points of interest in a given neighborhood.
One in a series of broadcasts belonging to a TV show or podcast.
A mobile operator's default network connection.
An instructional video showing how to perform certain functions on Windows Phone.
The label that indicates a call made to the phone.
The label that indicates a call made from the phone.
A Maps feature that shows the layout and location of stores in a shopping mall.
The option in Sounds settings. When this option is selected, the phone makes a sound when buttons on the on-screen keypad or keyboard are tapped.
A Facebook-established expression for showing approval of a friend’s post or connecting with a page.
A connection between multiple contact profiles in a network.
A list of two or more email inboxes that have been linked so that users can view their email from all linked accounts at the same time. The accounts themselves are not combined.
The feature accessed from Search or Maps that displays things to see and do, shopping, and restaurants in a user's current location and the surrounding area.
The feature accessed from Search or Maps that displays things to see and do, shopping, and restaurants in a user's current location and the surrounding area.
A set of services used by Windows and Windows apps to access the user's current location.
The tile in the Start screen that provides to the user quick access to post messages, check in to locations, or review notifications from various services and social networks.
The high-capacity color barcode (HCCB) with encoded information.
The official branded name of the Speech feature.
The free online service that's accessible through www.windowsphone.com. The main feature of this service is that users can find a lost phone.
An SD card that does not meet the requirements for use in a Windows Phone.
The title of the hub for music and video.
A status showing on the phone when the speaker is turned off and the person on the other line can't hear you.
The type of notebook listed in OneNote Notebooks screen.
Before Windows loads.
A profile that determines the network settings for the phone, and then activates or updates that phone.
A system of dividing up territory into independent areas for mobile telephony (voice and data connections), managed by mobile operators.
The title of a screen showing a list of all digital media (including music and videos) from Xbox Music that can be played on the phone.
A contact’s office number.
A selector that determines which cellular network type a phone will use.
The feature in Settings that provides options such as launching the camera, adding location info, and uploading pictures.
A digital media file (audio or video) released episodically and downloadable from the Internet.
The UI option to share a message on Windows Live, Facebook, or both.
The button that can be tapped during a conference call to have a private conversation with one person on the call.
A specific two-dimensional bar code that is used to provide easy access to information through a smartphone.
The option to rate the content and add a review of an app.
The feature to define the quick upload of images using a user-defined storing location (such as OneDrive or Facebook) to be listed in the context menu.
The options for setting the phone’s default language and the specific country or region where it is spoken.
The Games hub screen that shows nudges (reminders) to make the next move and “your turn” notifications in turn-based games, and invitations to play.
To repost a tweet from another Twitter user, sharing the tweet with one's own followers.
A short message on Twitter that you are resending to another audience.

A list of attactions (places and events) in a specific neighborhood.
A password given by the service provider to the user.
The tagline added to all email that's sent from a Windows device.
The credentials (user name and password) that a person uses to gain access to a service, network server, etc.

A toggle switch to request delivery notification via SMS.
The label of the picker box showing a list of Alarms and Alerts.

A price that reflects a representative value in other currencies. The specific price of a price tier that is shown in one currency will be close to the corresponding price in another currency. A value that developers specify in the app manifest for their Windows Store apps. Windows Store apps use capabilities to declare that the app requires programmatic access to protected user resources, such as the Pictures library, or connected devices, such as a webcam.

Pertaining to the chrome-free UI presentation mode that fills all or a portion of the display.
The download package that includes People, Messaging, Mail, and Calendar.
A feature of Internet Explorer 10 that allows users to easily switch between websites and their corresponding apps.
A set of apps that includes Messenger, Photo Gallery, Movie Maker, OneDrive, Mail, Writer, and Family Safety. (Family Safety is only included in Windows 7 downloads; it's built in to Windows 8.)

A Windows feature that enables users to connect computers with a simple tap gesture or by browsing for computers within wireless range. If two computers come within 3-4 centimeters of each other, or are tapped together, the operating system of each computer becomes aware of the other computer. Also, a user can browse for computers within wireless range that are advertising for a peer connection. The user can then connect the two computers to share content such as photos or links, or create a multi-player experience. If the connection is made using a tap gesture, the user can also publish and subscribe to messages transmitted during the tap.
A feature of Windows where a user's credentials are securely stored.
To take action on a message by either replying to the sender, to the sender and all recipients, or by forwarding the message to someone else.
A feature of Windows that provide right-click access from taskbar program buttons to the documents, pictures, songs, or websites a user frequently accesses.
A feature of Windows that provide right-click access from taskbar program buttons to the documents, pictures, songs, or websites a user frequently accesses.
A nonfinal release of Internet Explorer 10.
A short video sent as an email message to someone in the contact list.
A short video sent as an email message to someone in the contact list.
A technique that increases sharpness and fidelity by compensating for some effects that camera movement has on images in videos.
A technique that increases sharpness and fidelity by compensating for some effects that camera movement has on images in videos.

The cloud service that enables users to communicate and collaborate with people online and access their conversations, photos, documents, contacts, appointments, settings, and services across PC, phone, and other devices.
A visual interface where users enter a passcode, use a certain button combination or perform a certain gesture in order to activate the full functionality of a device.
A tool that allows users to upload email messages, email folders, and contacts from an email account on their PC to the cloud to facilitate access from multiple devices.
An image stabilization technique used to remove wobbled distortions from a video captured with a rolling shutter camera that's exposed to large accelerations or jitter.
An image stabilization technique that's used to reduce the appearance of camera shake in a video image.
The web browser component of Windows that provides a traditional and familiar browsing experience.
The touch-optimized, immersive web browser for Windows.
A document service that enables organizations to provision and manage online storage for their users.
A document service that enables organizations to provision and manage online storage for their users.
A feature that validates, signs, and stores boot information in the Trusted Platform Module chip to verify the integrity of the PC.
A feature of the Windows 8 Bing Weather app that lets users choose geographic locations in which to track weather and personalize the app with these choices
A feature of the Bing Finance app that lets users choose stocks to watch and personalize the app with these choices.
A chart that can be based on any table or query, can be created by any user, and can be added to all UI types.
A chart that is based on advanced data from a specific application area, can be edited by users, and can be added to Role Centers. Some specific charts are predefined and cannot be edited.
A gesture that enables proximity-based authentication between two devices.
To go to the next page on a site quickly by swiping across the page or clicking the Forward button.
A feature in Internet Explorer that enables users to go to the next page on a site quickly by swiping across the page or clicking the Forward button.
A button that shuts down or restarts the PC.
To remotely view, stream, or copy files stored on a PC running OneDrive from any other device.

An action by which a subscription (the source subscription) is replaced by a new subscription, both owned by the same billing account, along a preconfigured conversion path. The source subscription is canceled and the destination subscription is the new subscription.
A new subscription that is created as a result of a conversion or a merge.
A subscription that is canceled to create a new subscription as a result of a conversion or merge.
A partner in scenarios where the partner providing the offer is different than the partner providing the service, for example, Xbox selling Messenger products.
To replace a set of subscriptions with a new subscription.
The process of activating tokens during a purchase.
The process of activating tokens during a purchase.
A subscription that can only be paid with a prepaid card.
A company that provides reporting compliance services.
A company that provides reporting compliance services.
To remove the mapping from a folder to OneDrive.

The operating system designed for enthusiasts and business/technical pros that includes all of the features in Windows 8, plus features for encryption, virtualization, PC management, and domain connectivity.

The operating system for PCs and tablets powered by x86 (32-bit) and AMD (64-bit) processors that includes an updated Windows Explorer, Task Manager, better multi-monitor support, and fast language switching.

The operating system only available pre-installed on PCs and tablets powered by ARM processors that helps enable new thin and lightweight form factors with impressive battery life. Windows RT includes touch-optimized versions of Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and OneNote.
A downloadable pack that adds features to Windows 8 or Windows 8 Single Language editions to move them to a Windows 8 Pro edition with Windows Media Center installed.
An edition of Windows 8 that is available only through volume licensing.
An edition of Windows 8 designed to make Windows affordable to mainstream consumers in emerging markets.
A media pack add-on to Windows 8 Pro that upgrades the edition to include Windows Media Center.
The button or slider on tablets and convertible tablets that rotates the display.
An edition of Windows 8 Pro that contains Windows Media Center.
The release candidate release of the Windows 8 operating system.

An automated proactive scan that triggers when NTFS detects a corruption. The scan is equivalent to the scan phase of chkdsk and finds and logs all corruptions to an internal file. This scan runs during maintenance hours, can be triggered from the Explorer, or manually run from a command line. When this scan is running in the background, some NTFS operations may be blocked.

A registry setting that allows the DHCP client to transmit more messages to the server to obtain an IP address when the PC is in connected standby mode. This setting can increase power consumption but can also help resolve IP address (IPv4 or IPv6) problems more quickly.

A service within Remote Desktop Services responsible for aggregating RemoteApp programs and desktops that are published to end users from across the entire deployment. It ensure only users with appropriate rights can access published resources. The resources are used to display error messages that, for example, might say that the publishing service is unavailable. This can help the admin debug their deployment.
The capability to sign in to a PC by using a four-digit code.
A software setting that disables display rotation.

Data that shows how products are used including where, how often, with which other software and hardware. This data is used to identify user needs and experiences as well as potential marketing and product improvement opportunities over time. Partners and Microsoft can better understand what happens between planning, lab testing, sales data, and real world scenarios over time.

An app for Mac computers that creates a folder on the user's computer, downloads the contents of their OneDrive, and keeps the folder in sync with any file changes online and among additional computers.
A nonfinal release of Internet Explorer 10 that follows the consumer preview.
The automatic display of photos in Windows Photos in a grid-like pattern based on metadata from the photos that are connected to the user's account.
A function relevant to an app in use that is displayed on the app bar.
The charm that takes users to the Start screen.
The functionality that allows users to switch back to recently used apps.
The state that enables a PC to turn on instantly and have tiles and other services update even when the screen is off.
A collection of Windows and device settings that users can change grouped into one location.
A tablet hardware button with the Windows logo on it that's similar to the Windows key on a keyboard. Pressing the Power and Windows buttons simultaneously is the equivalent of pressing Ctrl+Alt+Del.
The spreading of malicious content through online advertising.
The spreading of malicious content through online advertising.
A rating of how safe an app is determined to be by SmartScreen, according to age, presence of digital certificate, and other criteria.
The Japanese kana characters that indicate the correct pronunciation, sorting, and grouping behavior of a word written in kanji.
A feature that provides a progressive disclosure method that remains active only as long as the user holds (presses down) their finger on the touch surface.
The charm that provides access to the devices commands.
A hardware button that increases and decreases the sound volume.
The UI label that indicates a screen or monitor that is attached to a PC and that content can be projected on to.
An application that comes with a product key and DVD that allows users them to purchase Windows and activate their current copy of Windows from the client.
A report generated by OEMs for each OA 3.0 manufactured computer which is then sent to Microsoft for processing. This report includes the hardware hash value and Product Key ID.
A report generated by OEMs for each OA 3.0 manufactured computer which is then sent to Microsoft for processing. This report includes the hardware hash value and Product Key ID.
Any problematic medical occurrence that may happen during a medical treatment involving drugs. The adverse event may not necessarily be caused by the drug treatment.
The age at which an individual first experiences an illness or symptoms of a sickness or disorder.
The amount of energy that is needed to support the body's most basic functions when at rest. The Basal metabolic rate (or BMR) is the number of calories a person needs per day to stay alive.
The amount of energy that is needed to support the body's most basic functions when at rest. The Basal metabolic rate (or BMR) is the number of calories a person needs per day to stay alive.

A measurement of the pressure that the body's blood is putting on the blood vessel walls.

A measurement of the pressure that the body’s blood is putting on the blood vessel walls. The measurement is displayed with the systolic pressure number over the diastolic pressure number (in millimeters of mercury).
A health device used to measure a person's blood pressure.
A measurement that shows the amount of minerals in one square centimeter of bones. A bone density measurement can be used as a possible marker of osteoporosis and fracture risk.

A technique that produces a computer-processed X-ray image of a cross section of an internal organ or tissue.
A technique that produces a computer-processed X-ray image of a cross section of an internal organ or tissue.

An illness or other defective state of health.
Someone who has full access to all the information in a record, with the ability to see, change, share, and delete any of that information.
The highest level of access.
Information such as age, education, income, and gender about the population in particular areas.
A non-proprietary data interchange protocol, digital image format, and file structure standard for biomedical images.

A SharePoint view that provides an optimized mobile browser experience for users and renders in HTML5.
A SharePoint view that renders in HTML format, or a similar markup language such as CHTML or WML, and provides backward compatibility for mobile browsers that cannot support the contemporary view.
A SharePoint feature that enables a single publishing site to be rendered differently for different mobile devices in order to optimize the user experience.
The version of software that's distributed to manufacturers to build into hardware they will make available when the final software is made generally available.
The version of software that's distributed to manufacturers to build into hardware they will make available when the final software is made generally available.
To reset a system using a method that restores PC settings to defaults but retains a user's files and personalization touches.
To reset a system so that all user customizations are removed.

The software package that makes updated management functionality available for installation in Windows and Windows Server. Windows Management Framework includes updated features and functionalities in components such as Windows PowerShell, Windows Remote Management (WinRM), and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).
A control that slows down the speed of panning from a user interaction.
The button that allows customers to finalize their purchase on a website.
The out-of-the-box encryption capabilities that are automatically included on PCs running Windows RT.
The button on a checkout screen that, when clicked, commits the buyer to a purchase agreement with the seller, as specified by EU guideline 2011/83/EU and other local laws.

The feature of Bing that enables customers to block sites containing adult (sexually explicit) content. Customers can choose from three levels of filtering: strict (hides adult text and image results); moderate (hides adult images only); and off (doesn't hide any search results).

A consumer subscription offering that includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint, OneNote, Outlook, Publisher, and Access across multiple devices plus Office services such as personalized experience, Office on Demand, Skype world minutes, additional OneDrive storage and ongoing access to upgrades.
An enterprise-level subscription offering that includes online service versions of Word, PowerPoint, Excel, Outlook, OneNote, Access, Publisher, and Lync.

An app that's downloaded from the Microsoft Store and installed automatically to the PC when a user attaches a certified device to the PC, provided that the device manufacturer has submitted the app to the Microsoft Store.
The set of look-and-feel elements (type, color, icons, etc.) that create a sense of brand and a cohesive user experience with Microsoft products.
The 2013 edition of the base consumer offering of the Office suite, which includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote.
The 2013 edition of the Office suite that supports common tasks for home and small business use, and that includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint, OneNote, and Outlook.
The 2013 edition of the Office suite that supports common business tasks, and that includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint, OneNote, Outlook, Publisher, Access, Lync, and InfoPath.

The subscription offering of the Microsoft project management software used to plan, manage, and communicate a project schedule and other information among team members, project managers and stakeholders, which supports SharePoint Online task list sync, Lync Online presence and connecting to Project Online.

descripGrp.descrip: A computing services model that uses a network of remote servers hosted on the internet to store, manage, and process data, rather than a local server or a personal computer.

The composition of two or more distinct cloud infrastructures (private, community, or public) which remain unique entities, but are bound together by standardized or proprietary technology that enables data and application portability (e.g., cloud bursting for load balancing between clouds).
A capability provided to the user for using the provider’s applications running on the cloud.

A cloud-computing model that allows user to develop, run, manage, and deploy applications within a cloud infrastructure, using supported technologies, without building and maintaining said infrastructure.

A cloud-computing model that allows user to develop, run, manage, and deploy applications within a cloud infrastructure, using supported technologies, without building and maintaining said infrastructure.

A signal that tells your Xbox Live and Facebook friends that you want to play a particular game, and notifies you when friends are playing or want to play that game.

The category of products (apps or games) that are current getting the best average overall rating by customers.

A description for music or videos stored in the cloud that users may access from their phone. Used for Xbox Music and any other potential cloud-based media services.
The amount of data the user can download/upload through the carrier's network each month without being billed additional charges.

The pre-loaded app that allows users to better monitor and manage their data usage on their phone or PC. It can notify users when they are close to their cellular data limit and delay some data-intensive tasks until the phone or PC is connected to Wi-Fi.
The button label to note that the user does not like a suggestion in Local Scout.
The default room name in the Rooms feature of the People Hub. Based on the concept of the "family room" in many homes, in which family and guests gather for group activities.

A place on the phone where families (or other close-knit groups) can stay in touch. Rooms take the form of a panorama that lives in the People Hub. The panorama includes a family chat card, a shared calendar, a shared photo album, and a shared notebook. Users ask others to join their Room via an SMS invite.
An NFC-enabled card (like a credit card) that users can use for payments or other transactions even when the phone is locked.
A flash mode used to set off the flash automatically according to the ambient light conditions.
A flash mode when the phone's built-in camera flash is set to off.
A flash mode when the phone's built-in camera flash is set to on.

A camera on the front of an electronic device (such as a smartphone), which faces the user. This allows the user to video chat with another person also using a front-facing device. It may also be used to take videos and pictures.
A text message thread between a group of people (usually more than 2). It allows you to keep all the replies from people in one thread, so that you can see the whole conversation.
The app that provides easy access to Help and how-to content as well as helpful tips for users.

An APN (Access Point Name) that determines the cellular data networks to which a phone can connect. It includes information about what kind of connection, security, and type of IP address the phone should use for the Internet connection.
The APN (Access Point Name) a phone can use to send MMS messages (text messages with multimedia files attached).
The company or organization that issued the user the card they're adding to their wallet. For example, an issuer could be a bank.

The title of the screen prompting the user to sign in to his existing Microsoft account or to create a Microsoft account. The app that helps parents provide their children with controlled access to their phones. In Kid's Corner, kids can only use the apps, games, and other content that parents select.
List of the top players in a game or other competition on Xbox Live.

A setting where the user provides the date when their monthly data usage resets to 0.

The feature that unifies components across applications, such as people, conversations, calendars, emails, and files, to create a seamless collaboration experience. Creating a group anywhere in Microsoft 365 will automatically provision a corresponding Yammer conversation feed, an Outlook inbox and calendar, and a SharePoint document library for every Group member. Groups make these components persistent across applications, so that changes made to components in part of Microsoft 365 will carry through to the others, thus enabling a unified experience.

A user account and associated credentials that is used to access Microsoft’s and 3rd parties’ business services, such as Office 365. Work or school accounts are usually assigned to end users by their organization (work, school, non-profit) and managed by the admin. However, some business services like Yammer support work or school accounts that were created by end users, without IT involvement. We sometimes refer to these accounts as “viral” AAD accounts but we don’t use this term externally. Work or school accounts are stored in Azure Active Directory (AAD) and managed by Microsoft on behalf of the organization. One of the key difference with a Microsoft account is that users don’t own the account and will typically loose access to it if they leave the organization. Other aspects like password policies are imposed by admins.

A user account and associated credentials that is used to access Microsoft’s and 3rd parties’ business services, such as Office 365. Work or school accounts are usually assigned to end users by their organization (work, school, non-profit) and managed by the admin. However, some business services like Yammer support work or school accounts that were created by end users, without IT involvement. We sometimes refer to these accounts as “viral” AAD accounts but we don’t use this term externally. Work or school accounts are stored in Azure Active Directory (AAD) and managed by Microsoft on behalf of the organization. One of the key difference with a Microsoft account is that users don’t own the account and will typically loose access to it if they leave the organization. Other aspects like password policies are imposed by admins.

An exercise workout session containing step by step activities to guide you from the beginning to the end of the workout
Pertaining to exercise intense enough to trigger lactate formation. It is used by athletes in non-endurance sports to promote strength, speed and power and by body builders to build muscle mass.
Pertaining to physical exercise that depends on oxygen and aerobic metabolism to meet energy demands. Aerobic exercise provides cardiovascular training benefits.
An exercise program that is designed to evoke initial training and instruction given to military recruits.

Any position of the human body where one leg is positioned forward with knee bent and foot flat on the ground while the other leg is positioned behind. It is used by athletes in cross-training for sports and by weight-trainers as a fitness exercise.
A full body exercise used in strength training and as an aerobic exercise involving standing, squatting, kicking and jumping.

An isometric core strength exercise that involves maintaining a difficult position for extended periods of time. The most common plank is the front plank which is held in a push-up position with the body's weight borne on forearms, elbows, and toes.

One of the most common abdominal exercises that primarily works the rectus abdominis muscle and the obliques. It begins with lying face up on the floor with knees bent. The movement begins by curling the shoulders towards the pelvis.
A full body exercise used in strength training and as an aerobic exercise involving standing, squatting, kicking and jumping.
A common calisthenics exercise performed in a prone position by raising and lowering the body using the arms.
A common calisthenics exercise performed in a prone position by raising and lowering the body using the arms.

An abdominal strength training exercise commonly performed to strengthen the abdominal muscles. It is similar to a crunch. It begins with lying with the back on the floor, typically with the arms across the chest or hands behind the head and the knees bent in an attempt to reduce stress on the back muscles and spine, and then elevating both the upper and lower vertebrae from the floor until everything superior to the buttocks is not touching the ground.

Exercises in which muscles exert maximum force in short intervals of time, with the goal of increasing both speed and power. This training focuses on learning to move from a muscle extension to a contraction in a rapid or "explosive" manner, for example with specialized repeated jumping.

Exercises in which muscles exert maximum force in short intervals of time, with the goal of increasing both speed and power. This training focuses on learning to move from a muscle extension to a contraction in a rapid or "explosive" manner, for example with specialized repeated jumping.

An exercise that works both the upper and lower abdominal muscles at the same time. They are carried out by lying down on your back on the floor or on a gym mat and then extend your arms behind your head. The back of your hands should touch the floor while your palms face the ceiling. Keep your feet together and your toes pointed toward the ceiling. To begin the exercise, keep your legs straight and lift them up, and at the same time raise your upper body off of the floor and reach for your toes with your hands. Squeeze your abdominal muscles as you reach for you toes, and then slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position to finish the first repetition.
A physical fitness system practiced as the art of controlled movements, which should look and feel like a workout (not a therapy) when properly manifested.
A dance fitness program involving dance and aerobic elements. The choreography incorporates hip-hop, soca, samba, salsa, merengue and mambo. Squats and lunges are also included.
Hyphenation of word "absolutely" to emphasize the word "abs" short for the rectus abdominis muscle.

The typical start page in Microsoft Dynamics AX. On the dashboard, users see a section for each workspace that they have access to. Each section displays the tiles from the summary sections in the related workspace. The dashboard consists of a name and sections with tiles.

A page that provides an overview of one of the activities that the user performs. Tiles shown in the summary section of the workspace are also displayed in the related section in the dashboard.

A tool that helps you manage support incidents by letting you create a virtual machine (VM) in Microsoft Azure that has the same hotfixes installed as your local environment.
A tool that lets you copy a configuration from one instance of Microsoft Dynamics AX 2012 R3 to another.

A tool that helps you estimate the number of licenses that an organization will need for Microsoft Dynamics AX 2012. It provides a shared workspace that lets you model default and customized roles, and then automatically calculate the required client access licenses (CALs).
A tool that provides an automated rough first estimate of the hardware needs of an environment.

A search engine that you can use to quickly search for Knowledge Base (KB) articles, hotfixes requested by customers and partners, proactive fixes, regulatory features, and workarounds for reported issues. You can also see which reported issues are in the process of being fixed. You can download released hotfixes, see which code objects are affected, and see the code changes introduced by the hotfix.

An automated tool that validates the customer’s model files against Microsoft Dynamics AX best-practice rules for tables, classes, forms, and enums. It then generates reports, including a summary report that is displayed on the site, a detailed Microsoft Excel report that lists all issues, and a developer report that the developer can load in the Microsoft Dynamics AX development environment.

A data-gathering tool that can help you describe your projected or current usage of a Microsoft Dynamics AX 2012 implementation. You can use the data from the Usage profiler for a variety of purposes, such as estimating infrastructure sizing.
A page in Lifecycle Services (LCS) that contains common questions found on requests for proposals (RFPs), and recommended answers.

A cloud-based tool that helps administrators monitor and understand the health of one or more Microsoft Dynamics AX environments.
